raw_text:
Rover deal 'may cost 2,000 jobs'
 
 Some 2,000 jobs at MG Rover's Midlands plant may be cut if investment in the firm by a Chinese car maker goes ahead, the Financial Times has reported.
 
 Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp plans to shift production of the Rover 25 to China and export it to the UK, sources close to the negotiations tell the FT. But Rover told BBC News that reports of job cuts were "speculation". A tie-up, seen as Rover's last chance to save its Longbridge plant, has been pushed by UK Chancellor Gordon Brown. Rover confirmed the tie-up would take place "not very far away from this time".
 
 Rover bosses have said they are "confident" the £1bn ($1.9bn) investment deal would be signed in March or early April.
 
 Transport & General Worker's Union general secretary Tony Woodley repeated his view on Friday that all mergers led to some job cuts. He said investment in new models was needed to ensure the future of the Birmingham plant. "This is a very crucial and delicate time and our efforts are targeted to securing new models for the company which will mean jobs for our people," he said. SAIC says none of its money will be paid to the four owners of Rover, who have been accused by unions of awarding themselves exorbitant salaries, the FT reports. "SAIC is extremely concerned to ensure that its money is used to invest in the business rather than be distributed to the shareholders," the newspaper quotes a source close to the Chinese firm. Meanwhile, according to Chinese state press reports, small state-owned carmaker Nanjing Auto is in negotiations with Rover and SAIC to take a 20% stake in the joint venture. SAIC was unavailable for comment on the job cuts when contacted by BBC News. Rover and SAIC signed a technology-sharing agreement in August.
llama3.2:1b: Some 2,000 jobs at MG Rover's Midlands plant may be cut if investment from Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp goes ahead, sources close to negotiations tell the Financial Times.
llama3.2:3b: 2000 jobs at MG Rover's Midlands plant may be cut if investment from Chinese car maker Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp goes ahead.
gemma2:2b: A Chinese car maker, SAIC, plans to shift production of the Rover 25 from the UK to China. This deal could lead to job cuts at MG Rover's Midlands plant if it goes ahead.  SAIC will invest £1 billion in Rover and aims to ensure this investment is used to develop new models. The Transport & General Worker's Union is concerned about job security for workers and the future of the Birmingham plant.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Rover, a British manufacturer of cars, has been asked if they can produce new models in China, where their old factory is located. While the company says it will continue to make its products, some people worry that this could mean job cuts at the factory in Britain. The Chinese car maker SAIC (SAIC General Motors) is involved and is concerned about jobs being lost at the Rover plant. Some people are worried that new models might not be as good as the old ones being made in Europe.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Rover's potential £1bn investment deal with SAIC could lead to up to 2,000 jobs being cut at its Midlands plant if it goes ahead. The move would see production of the Rover 25 transferred from China to UK factories and sold domestically. Despite speculation that job losses may occur, Rover CEO confirms it will sign the £1bn investment deal in March or April. The firm's future is considered crucial for employment and long-term viability. SAIC aims to secure a stake in the joint venture but has expressed concern over how funds will be utilized.
qwen2.5:3b: Some 2,000 jobs at MG Rover's Midlands plant may be cut if a tie-up with Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp (SAIC) goes ahead to shift production of the Rover 25 to China and export it back to UK is reported. However, Rover denies this. The deal would likely be signed in March or early April. Union leader Tony Woodley predicts job cuts due to investment in new models needed for future. SAIC says none of its money will go to current Rover owners accused of exorbitant salaries. Nanjing Auto is negotiating a 20% stake in the joint venture, but SAIC was unavailable on job cuts.
opencoder:1.5b: Rover deal may cost 2,000 jobs. Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp plans to shift production of Rover 25 to China and export it to the UK. The company's last chance to save its Longbridge plant has been pushed by UK Chancellor Gordon Brown. Investment in new models is needed to ensure future of the Birmingham plant. SAIC says none of its money will be paid to the four owners of Rover, who have been accused by unions of awarding themselves exorbitant salaries.

deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize the given text concisely while preserving key ideas and details. The user provided a detailed paragraph about Rover's potential job cuts due to a car maker's investment. 

First, I should identify the main points. The text mentions that 2,000 jobs might be cut atMG Rover's plant if China invests in them. It also notes that Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp is moving production to China and the UK. However, there are warnings about job cuts reported elsewhere.

I need to make sure the summary captures both the potential savings and the concerns about future job losses or salary increases. I'll mention the investment figure, the locations of production moves, and the uncertainty from different sources like the FT and BBC News.

It's important to note that Rover's confidence in signing the £1bn deal by March is also key. I should avoid mentioning all the details but ensure the summary is concise and covers the main points clearly.
</think>

Rover's 2,000 jobs could be cut if a Chinese car maker invests heavily in it. Meanwhile, Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp plans to move production of Rover parts to China and the UK. However, there are concerns about job cuts elsewhere, with some sources reporting that ROVER's longbridge plant might close "not very far away from this time." The investment deal is expected by March or April but could face uncertainty. Additionally, ROVER has a tie-up with SAIC for a joint venture, which might reduce jobs if the company takes 20% stakes in it.
tinyllama:1.1b: The FinanciaL Times has reported that some 2,000 jobs at MG Rovers' Midlands plant may be cut if an investment by the Chinese car maker Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp goes ahead. The company confirmed it plans to sign a tie-up with the UK Chancellor Gordon Brown, but Rovers' bosses have said they are confident of securing £1bn ($1.9bn) investment deal and that new models would mean jobs for its employees. The union general secretary Tony Woodley repeated his views on Friday that investments needed to secure the future of Birmingham plant, with efforts being targeted at securing new models. SAIC said none of its funds will be paid to the four owner companies of Rovers, who were accused by unionists of awarding themselves exorbitant salaries. Meanwhile, state-owned carmaker Nanjin Auto is in negotiations with Rovers and SAIC to take a 20% stake in the joint venture. No comment was received from Rovers or SAIC when contacted by the FinanciaL Times.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The text provided provides an overview of the situation regarding the potential job cuts at MG Rover's (Rover) Midlands plant if investment in the company by a Chinese car maker goes ahead, according to Financial Times reporting. This decision has sparked debate among workers and unions over the impact on local jobs and the future of British automotive manufacturing. The proposed merger between Rover and SAIC, however, remains under negotiation. Meanwhile, Chinese state media reports suggest that Nanjing Auto, a small state-owned carmaker, is also in negotiations with Rover and SAIC to take a 20% stake in the joint venture. The job cuts are expected to be announced soon by Rover and may involve around 2,000 employees losing their jobs. This raises concerns about the potential impact on local communities and local businesses.
phi:2.7b: Reports suggest that 2,000 jobs at MG Rover's plant may be cut if a Chinese car maker invests in the firm. The company is considering shifting production of the Rover 25 to China to export it to the UK and sources close to the negotiations told the Financial Times (FT) about this plan. However, the company has denied these reports. A deal between the companies could save the Longbridge plant, which is seen as MG Rover's last chance. The investment deal is expected to take place in March or early April. Transport and General Worker's Union general secretary Tony Woodley believes that mergers always lead to job cuts, but he also thinks that new models are necessary for the future of the Birmingham plant. Chinese state-owned carmaker Nanjing Auto is also reportedly in negotiations with Rover and SAIC to take a 20% stake in the joint venture.
orca-mini:3b: MG Rover's Midlands plant may lose up to 2,000 jobs if a Chinese car maker invests £1bn in the firm, according to reports. Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp plans to shift production of the Rover 25 to China and export it to the UK, but Rover told BBC News that reports of job cuts were "speculation". The tie-up has been pushed by UK Chancellor Gordon Brown, but Rover confirmed it would take place "not very far away from this time". Negotiations are ongoing, and SAIC has denied distributing salaries to shareholders. Nanjing Auto is also in talks to take a 20% stake in the joint venture.
hermes3:3b: MG Rover job cuts: 2000 jobs at risk if Chinese car maker invests, according to Financial Times.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A Chinese car maker, Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp (SAIC), is planning to shift Rover's production to China and export vehicles to the UK, potentially resulting in 2,000 job cuts at MG Rover's Midlands plant, according to reports. The UK Chancellor has pushed for the tie-up, which would see SAIC invest £1 billion ($1.9 billion) in Rover. Despite concerns from the Transport & General Worker's Union, Rover and SAIC remain confident about the deal being completed soon. Meanwhile, a smaller Chinese state-owned carmaker, Nanjing Auto, is reportedly negotiating a 20% stake in the joint venture with SAIC.
stablelm2:1.6b: Chinese car maker SAIC may cut some jobs at MG Rover's Midlands plant if an investment deal is approved, according to the Financial Times. The tie-up would shift production of the Rover from UK to China for export, but reports suggest it could result in job cuts due to £1bn ($1.9bn) investment by Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp. Rover confirmed the deal would take place "not very far away" from now. The company is confident the investment will be signed by March or early April.
granite3.1-dense:2b: A proposed £1bn investment deal between Chinese automaker Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp (SAIC) and MG Rover could lead to the loss of approximately 2,000 jobs at Rover's Midlands plant. The plan involves shifting production of the Rover 25 to China for export to the UK. Despite Rover confirming the deal's imminent signing by Chancellor Gordon Brown and stating confidence in the March or early April completion, job cuts remain a concern due to speculation from unions. SAIC is committed to investing in the business, not distributing funds to current shareholders who have faced union criticism for excessive salaries. Small state-owned carmaker Nanjing Auto is also reportedly negotiating a 20% stake in the joint venture. Rover and SAIC previously signed a technology-sharing agreement in August.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Around 2,000 jobs at MG Rover's Midlands plant may be cut if a planned investment by China's Shanghai Automotive Industry Corp (SAIC) proceeds, as SAIC intends to shift Rover 25 production to China and export it to the UK. Rover dismissed job cut reports as speculation, but the deal, seen as crucial for saving the Longbridge plant, has UK government backing. Rover expects the £1bn investment deal to be signed by March or April. Union leader Tony Woodley acknowledged that mergers often lead to job losses and stressed the need for investment in new models. SAIC insists its funds will be used for business investment, not shareholder payouts. Meanwhile, Nanjing Auto is reportedly negotiating to take a 20% stake in the joint venture. SAIC declined to comment on job cuts, and Rover and SAIC previously signed a technology-sharing agreement in August.
